results.title: Savage indictment (A)
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Adler, Caroline Sherwood, Channel Four Television and Titus Films
results.brief_description: A look at Australia in the 1960’s through a court case against James Savage, an Aborigine, who was on trial in the United States for murder. Gives an account of the government policy which removed half-caste Aboriginal children from their natural parents and placed them with white families. Includes interviews with some of those children who are now grown up. Savage was sentenced to death in January 1990, a sentence subsequently commuted to life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicholas Adler, Caroline Sherwood, Channel Four Television and Titus Films

results.title: Sauvage et Beau = Wild and Beautiful
results.brief_description:
Animals are shown in activities that sustain their lives and keep the cycle of regeneration turning. Quotes from Gustave Flaubert and Guy de Maupassant give an unusual literary dimension to the scenes.

Credits: Director, Frederic Rossif ; writer, Jacques Tremolin ; photography, Daniel Barreau ; music, Vangelis Papathanassiou.
Cast: Richard Berry [narration].

results.title: Sausalito
results.brief_description: Utilising an imaginative rather than a realistic approach, the director Frank Stauffacher, one of the leading experimental film makers in the United States, seeks to capture the atmosphere of Sausalito, a small village on the shore of San Francisco Bay. The film is divided into two sections; Landscape and Song and uses slow motion, split screen, and superimposition techniques. It consists of fragments of visual and auditory experience such as the lapping of water on the shore, the creaking redwood of old houses.

results.title: Saul Alinsky went to war
results.creator_credit: Peter Pearson, Donald Brittain, John Kemeny, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Challenge for change/Societe nouvelle”.
Saul Alinsky, controversial professional organiser, goes to war against the conditions that keep the poor in poverty. The film shows how he helped Black ghettos in the United States find an effective, non-violent method of fighting for their rights. (Awards: New York; Columbus.)

results.title: Sauk-Ai
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones, Shelah Reljic, John Taylor and Tony Westman
results.brief_description: Based on a legend of the Tsimshian Indians of British Columbia, this film is about a spirit called Raven who takes the shape of a man. One day, as he is searching for food, he meets Salmon Woman who embodies the Spirit of the Salmon. Their life together unfolds in harmony until Raven forgets his happiness and turns on his wife in anger. Underlying this simple tale is the timeless reality of how fragile are the links between people and how easily they can be ruptured. This film is partly animated by Howard Pedlar and stars Frank Austin as “Raven” and Darlene Malczewska as “Salmon Woman”.

results.title: Satyajit Ray: creative artist of India
results.creator_credit: Contemporary Films, Indian Government Information Service and B.D. Garga
results.brief_description: A behind-the-camera portrait of one of the world’s greatest film makers. Ray himself provides the commentary, in which he talks of his development as a writer and director. In particular, he develops the theme that through the medium of film he has not only reached a greater understanding of his own country, but has also found a greater universal understanding. Illustrated by scenes from The Apu Trilogy.

results.title: Saturn's return
results.creator_credit: Wenona Byrne, Christos Tsiolkas and Helen Pankhurst
results.brief_description: ‘Saturn’s return’ is part of an SBS commissioned series called ‘Hybrid Life’, which explores the experience of second and third generation migrants. Barney and his lover Dimi set out on a road trip to visit Barney’s father who is dying of AIDS and has decided to end his life. Based on a short story by Christos Tsiolkas and directed by Wenona Byrne, the film uses the road movie journey as a means to travel through Australia’s chequered history, while the two lovers confront their families turbulent past.

results.title: Saturn's return
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, Helen Pankhurst and Wenona Byrne
results.brief_description: Two men in love, Barney (Joel Edgerton) and Dimi (Damian Walshe-Howling) head up to Sydney from Melbourne on a road trip. Whilst on the way, the boys make a stop at Bonegilla, a migrant camp used in the 1950’s where Dimi’s parents had first met and lived. They continue onto Sydney, where Barney’s father, an aged-hippie struggles with the day-to-day practicalities of “living” with a terminal illness. As both Barney and Dimi’s love for each other intensifies, they revisit past memories as they address new experiences that test a maturing relationship. Issues of race, drugs, sexuality and family are brought to the surface with an affecting warmth that endears us to the characters. Story and screenplay written by Christos Tsiolkas.

results.title: Saturday school
results.creator_credit: Rick Cavaggion, Georgia Allan and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Ethnic language schools have been a part of Australia’s educational history since the 1850’s. However, until the advent of multiculturalism in the early 1970s, ethnic language schools were treated with disdain by the mainstream educational authorities who believed in assimilation programs for migrants rather than a continuing of cultural and linguistic ethnic traditions. In this video, the South Australian model for ethnic schools is investigated, including sources of financial assistance; the important work the schools do in maintaining respect for langauge and culture; and the role the schools now have in teaching new languages to children from English-speaking backgrounds.
